title: How secure are keyless door locks? - Quora

response.answer_text: With a traditional door lock, in order to bypass it one needs to be physically in front of the lock with lock picks. Only a few burglars who live close enough to me have the incentives to physically attack my traditional door lock. With a “smart” door lock connected to the Internet, you can bypass it from anywhere in the world. There are a lot of people—probably millions—around the world with incentives to attack your “smart” door lock. Imagine, for example, ransomware running on it that won’t allow you to enter until you pay.  And you have to protect that “smart” lock from the best attackers on the planet—not just the few that live physically close. With a traditional door lock, if you find a way to bypass one of them, you still need to physically go to each door to bypass another. With a “smart” door lock, once a way to bypass one of them is found, you can easily bypass all of them connected to the internet everywhere in the world. With a traditional door lock, you have pieces of metal that mechanically work together with one purpose—allowing those with a key to get in while keeping those without a key out. It’s not perfect, but it is well-understood. A traditional door lock cannot be turned against you. With a “smart” door lock, you have something that can be compromised by electronic attackers, and then used as a jumping off point to other electronic attacks on your other networked devices. With a traditional door lock, there is no chance of it becoming obsolete. It will continue to work as designed until it mechanically fails. With a “smart” door lock, if the manufacturer goes out of business, or end-of-lifes the product, or decides that it will no longer support users in your country—turning off it’s servers that support it, you can find yourself locked out of your own door with little or no warning. If needed, we could discuss specific vulnerabilities found in specific “smart” door locks, and there are plenty of these. But that’s just redundant. The problems with “smart” door locks are inherent in the concept.

Do key entry door systems make your property secure? Digital or smart locks are marmite-level divisive in the security community. Some love them, some hate them, and both sides are pretty much right. Good-quality, professionally-fitted keyless entry door locks are safe, but will they make your property safer than the locks you already have? High-quality locks are vital to securing your property, and anything inside it, but whether a smart lock is right for you, is dependent on the property and your user needs. There are a wide range of door entry systems that will make your property secure. It’s important to remember that the main flaw in a property security system isn’t the lock, but the user. Most burglars are opportunists, and will often enter into the house through an unlocked door or by forcing open a window or door. Although good quality locks can be an important security measure, this is only the case if you actually use them. Advantages of using keyless door entry systems They’re keyless.
